default.title: Invention
default.definition: The action of inventing something that has never been made before, or the item that is created.
default.contextualMeaning: Refers to the creation of a new product, idea, or process. It implies originality and novelty.
default.exampleSentence: The invention of the internet completely changed how we access information.
default.etymology: From late Middle English, via Old French from Latin 'inventio(n-)', from 'invenire' meaning 'to find'.

default.title: Unspecified
default.definition: Not stated clearly or in detail.
default.contextualMeaning: Used to describe something that is known to exist but has not been given a specific name, time, or detail.
default.exampleSentence: The meeting will take place at an unspecified location to ensure privacy.
default.etymology: From 'un-' (not) + the past participle of 'specify'.

default.title: Idiom
default.definition: A group of words established by usage as having a meaning not deducible from those of the individual words.
default.contextualMeaning: A common phrase or expression whose figurative meaning is different from its literal meaning, often unique to a specific language or culture.
default.exampleSentence: The phrase 'it's raining cats and dogs' is a popular English idiom.
default.etymology: From late 16th century French 'idiome', via late Latin from Greek 'idiōma' meaning 'private property, peculiar phraseology'.

default.title: Boundaries
default.definition: A line which marks the limits of an area; a dividing line. Can also refer to the limits of what is acceptable or possible.
default.contextualMeaning: Often used figuratively to refer to the limits of social conventions, rules, or personal comfort zones.
default.exampleSentence: Great artists often push the boundaries of what is considered traditional art.
default.etymology: From Old French 'bodne', later 'borne', of Gaulish origin.

default.title: Acceptable
default.definition: Able to be agreed on; suitable. Satisfactory or good enough.
default.contextualMeaning: Describes something that meets a certain minimum standard or is considered socially appropriate.
default.exampleSentence: While his performance wasn't amazing, it was acceptable for a beginner.
default.etymology: From late Middle English, from Old French, from the verb 'accepter'.

default.title: Fresh
default.definition: (Of food) recently made or obtained; not canned, frozen, or otherwise preserved.
default.contextualMeaning: Emphasizes that food is natural and has not been processed for long-term storage, often implying better taste and quality.
default.exampleSentence: She prefers to buy fresh vegetables from the farmer's market.
default.etymology: Old English 'fersc' meaning 'fresh, new, unsalted', of West Germanic origin.

default.title: Popular
default.definition: Liked, admired, or enjoyed by many people or by a particular person or group.
default.contextualMeaning: Indicates widespread appeal and acceptance among a general audience.
default.exampleSentence: That new song has become very popular on social media platforms.
default.etymology: From late Middle English, via Old French from Latin 'popularis', from 'populus' meaning 'people'.

default.title: Origins
default.definition: The point or place where something begins, arises, or is derived.
default.contextualMeaning: Refers to the source, beginning, or ancestry of something, whether it be an idea, object, or person.
default.exampleSentence: The museum has an exhibit on the origins of human civilization.
default.etymology: From Old French 'origine', from Latin 'origo, origin-' from 'oriri' meaning 'to rise'.

default.title: Recipes
default.definition: A set of instructions for preparing a particular dish, including a list of the ingredients required.
default.contextualMeaning: A guide or formula for making something, most commonly used for food but can be used metaphorically for achieving a certain result.
default.exampleSentence: My grandmother keeps her secret family recipes in an old notebook.
default.etymology: From Latin 'recipe' meaning 'receive!', the imperative of 'recipere'.

default.title: Spread
default.definition: Extend over a large or increasing area; open out from a folded position.
default.contextualMeaning: Can refer to the physical distribution of things over an area or the dissemination of information, ideas, or influence.
default.exampleSentence: News of the event began to spread quickly online.
default.etymology: Old English 'sprǣdan', of West Germanic origin.

default.title: Traders
default.definition: A person who buys and sells goods, currency, or stocks.
default.contextualMeaning: Refers to people engaged in commerce, often historically implying travel and the exchange of goods between different cultures.
default.exampleSentence: Ancient traders traveled long distances to exchange silk for spices.
default.etymology: From Middle Low German 'trade' meaning 'track, course', related to 'tread'.

default.title: Destination
default.definition: The place to which someone or something is going or being sent.
default.contextualMeaning: The final point in a journey or the end goal of a process.
default.exampleSentence: After a long flight, we finally arrived at our holiday destination.
default.etymology: From late Middle English, via Old French from Latin 'destinatio(n-)', from 'destinare' meaning 'to determine'.

default.title: Flavour (Flavor)
default.definition: The distinctive taste of a food or drink.
default.contextualMeaning: Can also refer to the general character or quality of something.
default.exampleSentence: The chef added a unique combination of herbs to give the soup a rich flavour.
default.etymology: From Old French 'flaur', probably from a source related to Latin 'flatus' meaning 'a blowing'.

default.title: Ingredients
default.definition: Any of the foods or substances that are combined to make a particular dish.
default.contextualMeaning: The components or elements that make up a whole, whether a food, product, or abstract concept.
default.exampleSentence: Always read the list of ingredients to check for potential allergens.
default.etymology: From Latin 'ingredient- ' from 'ingredi' meaning 'to enter'.

default.title: Varieties
default.definition: The quality or state of being different or diverse; the absence of uniformity or monotony.
default.contextualMeaning: Refers to a number of different types or kinds of something.
default.exampleSentence: The store offers a wide range of apple varieties, from sweet to tart.
default.etymology: From French 'variété' or Latin 'varietas', from 'varius' meaning 'diverse'.

default.title: Investigated
default.definition: Carried out a formal or systematic inquiry to discover and examine the facts of an incident, allegation, etc., so as to establish the truth.
default.contextualMeaning: To look into a matter deeply and methodically to find out what happened.
default.exampleSentence: The police investigated the cause of the mysterious fire.
default.etymology: From Latin 'investigare', from 'investigium' meaning 'a footprint, a trace'.

default.title: Uncovered
default.definition: Discovered something secret or previously unknown.
default.contextualMeaning: To reveal or bring to light something that was hidden, concealed, or not known before.
default.exampleSentence: The journalist uncovered a major political scandal through her research.
default.etymology: From 'un-' (not) + 'covered'.

default.title: Exotic
default.definition: Originating in or characteristic of a distant foreign country.
default.contextualMeaning: Describes something that is attractive or striking because it seems unusual and fascinating due to its foreign origin.
default.exampleSentence: She decorated her home with exotic plants from Southeast Asia.
default.etymology: From Greek 'exōtikos', from 'exō' meaning 'outside'.

default.title: Association
default.definition: A group of people organized for a joint purpose; a connection or cooperative link between people or organizations.
default.contextualMeaning: An official group or organization with a common goal, or a mental connection between ideas.
default.exampleSentence: He joined the local historical association to learn more about his town.
default.etymology: From medieval Latin 'associatio(n-)', from the verb 'associare'.

default.title: Promote
default.definition: Support or actively encourage (a cause, venture, or aim); further the progress of.
default.contextualMeaning: To help something grow, develop, or increase in popularity, often through advertising or public support.
default.exampleSentence: The campaign was designed to promote awareness of environmental issues.
default.etymology: From late Middle English, from Latin 'promovere', from 'pro-' (forward) + 'movere' (to move).

default.title: Manufacturing
default.definition: The process of making articles on a large scale using machinery.
default.contextualMeaning: Refers to the industrial production of goods from raw materials.
default.exampleSentence: The city's economy is heavily based on automobile manufacturing.
default.etymology: From 'manufacture', from French, from Latin 'manu' (by hand) + 'factura' (a working), from 'facere' (to make).

default.title: Meaning
default.definition: What is meant by a word, text, concept, or action; the significance or purpose of something.
default.contextualMeaning: The idea or message that is intended to be conveyed.
default.exampleSentence: Philosophers have long debated the meaning of life.
default.etymology: From the verb 'mean', from Old English 'mǣnan'.

default.title: Foreign
default.definition: Of, from, in, or characteristic of a country or language other than one's own.
default.contextualMeaning: Describes something that is from outside one's own country, or something that is strange and unfamiliar.
default.exampleSentence: It can be challenging to learn a foreign language as an adult.
default.etymology: From Old French 'forain', based on Latin 'foras' meaning 'out of doors'.

default.title: Localise (Localize)
default.definition: Adapt (a product or content) to a specific language or culture so that it seems natural to that particular region.
default.contextualMeaning: To make something local in character; to modify something to fit the preferences and culture of a specific area.
default.exampleSentence: The company decided to localise its software for the Japanese market.
default.etymology: From 'local' + '-ise'. 'Local' is from late Latin 'localis', from 'locus' meaning 'place'.

default.title: Slices
default.definition: Thin, broad pieces of food, such as bread, meat, or cake, cut from a larger portion.
default.contextualMeaning: Portions cut from a whole, often implying thinness and flatness.
default.exampleSentence: She put a few slices of cucumber and tomato in her sandwich.
default.etymology: From Old French 'esclice', from 'esclicier' meaning 'to splinter'.

default.title: Gradually
default.definition: In a gradual way; slowly; by degrees.
default.contextualMeaning: Describes a process that happens slowly and steadily over a period of time, not suddenly.
default.exampleSentence: The sky gradually became darker as the sun set.
default.etymology: From 'gradual', from medieval Latin 'gradualis', from 'gradus' meaning 'step'.

default.title: Response
default.definition: A verbal or written answer; a reaction to something.
default.contextualMeaning: An answer, reply, or reaction to a stimulus, question, or event.
default.exampleSentence: We are still waiting for a response to our official inquiry.
default.etymology: From Old French 'respons', from Latin 'responsum', from 'respondere' meaning 'to answer'.

default.title: Traditional
default.definition: Existing in or as part of a tradition; long-established.
default.contextualMeaning: Describes customs, beliefs, or methods that have been passed down through generations and are considered standard or conventional.
default.exampleSentence: Many families have a traditional meal they eat on holidays.
default.etymology: From 'tradition', from Latin 'traditio(n-)', from 'tradere' meaning 'deliver, hand over'.
